document.masterDocTitle: Revision of Beroidae (Ctenophora) in the southern seas of Europe: systematics and distribution based on genetics and morphology

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of Beroidae (Ctenophora) in the southern seas of Europe: systematics and distribution based on genetics and morphology

subSubSection.paragraph:
Beroe ovata Bosc, 1802
(
Harbison et al. , 1978
).

Beroe ovata Chamisso & Eysenhardt, 1821
( Mayer, 1912 ) (see for complete synonyms until 1912).

Beroe â€˜ ovata â€™ Eschscholtz, 1829
(
Mills et al. , 1996
).

Beroe ovata Mayer 1912
(
Seravin et al. , 2002
).

Beroe ovata sensu Mayer 1912
(
Bayha et al. , 2004
).

Beroe ovata
has a wide, mitre-shaped flattened body, extended laterally in the voluminous stomodaeum ( Fig. 3A, B ). The lateral compression of the
Beroe ovata
body is remarkable, being more than three times flattened in the paragastral plane ( Fig. 3B ). It does not have an infundibular canal. The aboral end is rounded ( Fig. 3C ), while the oral end is almost straight and wider than the body width in adult individuals, which is characteristic only for
B. ovata
. Adult length is 50â€“160 mm ( Fig. 3A, B ), the length to width ratio (l/w) equals 1.1â€“1.2 (
Seravin et al. , 2002
; Shiganova & Malej, 2009 ). The meridional canals lie under eight rows of ciliary combs, which extend about three-quarters of the distance from the apical sense organ towards the mouth. Side branches (diverticulae) may be placed in connection to one another by means of an anastomosing network in the body ( Fig. 3C, D ) and, in addition, establishing a circle of an oral canal system. Like all species of genus
Beroe
,
B. ovata
has a wide-flaring mouth and large stomodaeum with powerful macrocilia on the walls near the mouth, three teeth with the middle tooth larger. Teeth help the ctenophore to capture whole prey or to bite part of prey ( Tamm & Tamm, 1993 ). The polar plate surrounding the sense organ at the aboral pole and is not fringed with a row of branched papillae ( Fig. 3D ).
Beroe ovata
is pink, while the largest adults are more intensely tinged brown and the plates are bioluminescent green.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 2. Illustrations by the premier describers of genus
Beroe
. A, Browne (1756) ; B, Bosc (1802) ; C, Chamisso & Eysenhardt (1821) .

Figure 3.
Beroe ovata
from the Black Sea. A, general view: PC â€“ paragastal canal; STC â€“subtetacular meridional canal; SC â€“ subsugital canal; a â€“ anastomoses; d â€“ diverticular. B, oral view of the body: M â€“ mouth; MA â€“ macrocilia. C, aboral part of body: A â€“ aboral pole; I â€“ infundibulum. D, part of body with canals: a â€“ anastamoses, d â€“ diverticular (photos by T. Shiganova).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Geographical distribution: Beroe ovata
is the only species of
Beroe
that became an invasive, being introduced with ballast water into European waters. Consequently, besides the native regions, now its habitats include established populations in the recipient areas.
